data.text: Bicycle Touring Through a Grizzly Country Advices

- Big thank to those of you who took the time to leave helpful comments! - Hi, I'm wondering how you all prepare yourself for cycling in bear country? I'm going to ride the TransAmerica Bicycle Trail this summer and I'll be going across Idaho, Montana, and Wyoming where grizzlies live. I'm looking for advice about cycling in bear country, especially Grizzly country. I'm specifically thinking about food storage as carrying a bear canister seems impossible, as well as what are the safety tips for cycling in Grizzly country? I will be carrying bear spray and I will make sure to not sleep with my food, but any advice or/and wisdom from previous encounters with bears are welcome! Also, wondering if some folks out here have done the TransAmerica Bicycle Trail and know if it's common to encounter Grizzlies while cycling the Idaho/Montana/Wyoming section? Thank you all!

data.text: I live in Montana and frequently ride my mountain bike on a section of the Great Divide trail in the Swan Valley. Last year, a lady riding the divide was killed when a grizzly entered her tent in Ovando. That was an unforced error on her part.. She had food in her tent. Just be smart and research standard precautions for bear country. Other than a surprise encounter with a bear (aka blind corner) or getting between a sow and her cubs, grizzly bears will try to avoid you just like any other wild animal. Stay alert and make noise. They aren't going to hunt you down. Most bear attacks are defensive. Read up on and follow all standard rules for camping in bear country. BTW, a bear canister isn't designed to keep you safe and it isn't scent proof. Its simply designed to keep the bear from gaining a reward for raiding improperly stored food. Don't be afraid. The rewards of riding in a pristine natural environment is unforgettable. Personally I'm more afraid of mountain lions than I am of bears and even that doesn't keep me out of the woods.

data.text: I cycled across Canada and round Alaska a few years ago, mostly wildcamping. I carried bear spray in a holster strapped to my top tube and stored food in an ursack (bear proof bag you can tie on to a tree. I attempted to hang food a few times at the start and often found it difficult to find a suitable tree, so bought an ursack. They let me use it through Denali national park too, I know some parks insist you use a cannister. Don't bother with bells, use you voice. Yell around corners and entertain yourself making up many bear songs. I had a few close encounters, but thankfully lots of arm waving and loud singing and they all lolloped off. I also learnt the hard way not to take the safety catch off the bearspray until actually going to spray ü§£ I'm sure I gave the bear a good laugh!
